docs.abstract: Think Cool Whip and a Keebler crust. (Then make them from scratch.)
docs.snippet: Think Cool Whip and a Keebler crust. (Then make them from scratch.)
docs.lead_paragraph: A few days before Thanksgiving, I visited my friend Hrishikesh Hirway at his home in Los Angeles. The first thing I noticed was the unusual group of ingredients sitting on his kitchen counter: a container of Cool Whip, a premade graham-cracker crust and a can of Alphonso mango purée. No matter how I tried to make sense of this combination, I couldn’t get it to add up to anything recognizable.

headline.main: A Very American Mango Pie, Inspired by Indian Aunties

docs.lead_paragraph: I am of advanced years but still exercise my profession. Not long ago, after I gave a seminar in my field, a young professional approached me with some questions that I happily answered. We kept in touch, and I became his mentor.

headline.main: Was I Wrong to Tell a Friend’s Partner About His Infidelity?
headline.print_headline: Was I Wrong to Tell a Friend’s Partner About His Infidelity?

docs.abstract: Don’t lead with your strongest points. Anticipate miscommunication. Lower your voice.
docs.snippet: Don’t lead with your strongest points. Anticipate miscommunication. Lower your voice.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Be attentive to the reasons someone might disagree with you,” says Fanele Mashwama, whose two-person team won the World Universities Debating Championship in 2016. It isn’t enough, in other words, to dwell only on the strengths of your own position. Accept that an issue like whether to increase the minimum wage, for example, can have strong reasons on both sides. “I could give very good considerations in favor of my side of the policy,” Mashwama says, “but those might not be relevant in light of the actual reasons my opponent has an opposing opinion.” This is common on social media, he adds; too often, people aren’t listening to one another. So rather than lead with your strongest arguments, start by interrogating those of your adversary.

docs.abstract: His doctors didn’t see that a pink patch on his skin and some nerve issues added up to one thing.
docs.snippet: His doctors didn’t see that a pink patch on his skin and some nerve issues added up to one thing.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Can you take a look at this?” the 50-year-old man asked his wife. Standing in front of the bathroom mirror in his home outside Asheville, N.C., he turned his head and touched an area on his cheek just in front of his ear. He could feel the smooth, slightly raised surface, but it was on the side of his face, in a spot that was hard for him to see. It was slightly pink, about the size of a 50-cent piece, with irregular borders. “Where did that come from?” his wife asked as she turned his head to get a better look. It didn’t hurt, he told her. In fact, that whole part of his face, right up to the middle of his ear, was kind of numb.

headline.main: A Man Discovers He Has a Disease Most People Thought No Longer Existed
headline.print_headline: The man had a spot on his face that would not go away. He was shocked to discover that he had a disease that he thought no longer existed.

docs.abstract: No ghosting, no treacle. Be direct. Consider a little booster in the form of a smiley emoji.
docs.snippet: No ghosting, no treacle. Be direct. Consider a little booster in the form of a smiley emoji.
docs.lead_paragraph: Keep it straightforward. “I usually go about being very direct, just telling the person I’m not interested,” says Gerald Elbasani, who, according to Tinder, is one of the most right-swiped users, or desired matches, on the app in the United States. Honesty is ideal; it shows respect for the other person’s time and intentions. Don’t give false excuses — you’ve been really busy on the job, for example, or you’re just extremely tired — because those offer follow-up openings when your work project or nap is done. Be direct and concise about your lack of interest; drawing it out doesn’t help anyone.

headline.main: How to Reject an Online Suitor
headline.print_headline: How to Reject an Online Suitor

docs.abstract: A lot of would-be presidents are clever people. Few have a cleverness so well targeted toward liberal intellectuals.
docs.snippet: A lot of would-be presidents are clever people. Few have a cleverness so well targeted toward liberal intellectuals.
docs.lead_paragraph: Late this March, a Norwegian news outlet sprang a surprise question on Pete Buttigieg, the mayor of South Bend, Ind., and candidate for president. The previous week, the writer Anand Giridharadas, who has close to half a million Twitter followers, tweeted that he met Buttigieg and introduced him to a Norwegian friend. “Instantaneously,” he wrote, “Mayor Pete starts talking to her in Norwegian, like a magic trick.” Apparently Buttigieg had read a Norwegian novel in translation and been so taken by it that he learned the language just to finish the author’s untranslated works.

headline.main: How Pete Buttigieg’s Meaningless Erudition Made Him the ‘Smart’ Candidate
